Excellent video. But one thing was wrong, that the amplification of the waves varies with the electromagnetic absorption extent. This absorption extent depends on the bulk of the substance and not the surface area, as the internal as well as external absorption happens within the grape. Also, there is a continuous absorption and deflection of the microwaves within the grape, which does not allow the waves to escape out, somewhat similar to an optical medium in which light gets trapped as a result of total internal reflection. That's why the amplification, and therefore the concentration of the electromagnetic waves is maximum at the centre of the grape, and hence the two fields of electromagnetism interact with each other because of ionisation of periarieal air.

The way incandescent lamps explode is a similar bizarre plasma phenomenon.

Likely the filament acts as a sort of tesla coil, because the magnetic pulse of the rapidly breaking filament pulls the generated metal ion plasma into the "bore" of the coiled filament and so (bridging the turns one by one) makes of it a dead short with much lower resistance than the tungsten wire itself. It so draws hundreds of amps current converted into heat until the bulb explodes if there is no proper fuse wire inside the glass stem (which can fail and cause plasma too) or at least trips the main fuse of the room (like with most nowadays Chinese bulbs).

This is barely documented by the lamp industry and deserves to be properly investigated by physics.

The water content leading to resonance at many contiguous frequencies instead of at discrete frequencies is similar to the electronics concept of circuit q or quality. A combination of pure capacitance and inductance can lead to resonance at a very narrow frequency band. However, adding a resistor whose value rivals or exceeds the individual impedances of the capacitor or inductor broadens the gain function peaks, although the gain peaks decrease.

How does this translate to our bodies and the microwaves we are constantly exposed to from wireless? One thing that struck me in this video is how I have long been told that microwaves heat from the inside and yet then I am told that the microwaves from wireless do not penetrate our skin. This does not make sense. I happen to be highly electrosensitive. If I put myself in high wireless environments I get flushed and heated in my head. Long term exposure leads me to have a full body ache, creaky joints, foggy brain and insomnia.

I have eliminated all wireless at my home and even sleep in a faraday cage made from material with silver fibers to keep myself functioning. I would love to see some experiments with lower level microwaves and how they effect living matter.

EASY EXPLANATION:
Think magnifying glass under the sun. In this case:
- 'magnifying glass' doesn't have to change angle (because it's spherical)
- 'magnifying glass' doesn't have to change distance (because the wavelength matches the grape length)

You know how light reflects off the water's surface? If you shine a light from underwater, light still reflects back down.
In the same way, the microwave goes through the grape, bounces off the inside surface and creates an echo chamber.

Your video was just sent to me on Facebook today. I am the co-author of two peer-reviewed papers on the 4th state of water (i.e. TOSH) with an electro-chemist, Klaus Oehr. While I understand why the explanation offered herein is an intuitively appealing one, it may not be the one and only explanation of this phenomenon. Without reading the paper cited yet, here is my early take: Microwaving grapes do not "create plasma" as such. What microwaves do is release the plasma (i.e. photons) that is/are already present and stored in various molecules within, which absorbed during the photosynthesis process as virtual electrons. One could say they excite the z-axis pi-electrons in ring molecules so as to re-release those photons that were absorbed through photosynthesis during the growing process. All living beings that have contact with the sun's light or that inhale/repirate photon rich oxygen and nitrogen from the atmosphere would do no less. However, the focusing aspect of the microwave proposition is likely correct. The question is just how that focusing mechanism is enough to attain the energy levels needed to liberate or reconvert those virtual pi-electron fields back into the pure plasma from whence they came?

Different explanation here. The skin on the grape acts as an isulator. When the microwaves travel across the grapes a voltage is generated to a level where the "insulation" breaks down causing an arc flash. This arc flash ionizes the air and rises with the heat generated. The voltage across an arc is typically 100 volts. The arc temperature should be 35k f or 4 times hotter than the sun but this only last for a few ms as the arc is initiated before separation of the grapes. Try taking the grape skins off to test this theory. Cheers

@Veritasium
watching the plasma you can tell what elements are involved by the colour of the plasma.
When you burn Potassium it produces a purple flame and sodium produces orange.
In the EM graph the Potassium peak is much greater than the Sodium one (in the grapes) and when you "nuke" the grapes the first and largest burst of plasma is lilac-purple followed by a much smaller, orange burst. When you have a change in impedance you get reflections of the waves. Change in impedance is often expressed at higher frequencies as index of refraction, but in lower frequencies its epsilon relative (change in electric permitivity). This is because at higher frequencies the area that is effected by diffraction is much smaller, and thus its simplified to index of refraction. If you applied the same maxwell's equations to higher frequencies you'd get the same results as doing the math with index of refraction, its just a lot more work.

Thus that's why the grape acts like an internal reflector. The change in impedance causes the reflection coefficient to be so large that much of the energy is reflected back inside the grape rather than transmitted back into the air.

The same thing happens with a mirror, it has a massive reflection coefficient, across a decent range of frequencies (something not easy to always do). And this is how you create materials that are non reflective, you design the material to have a very small reflection coefficient. Doing that over broad frequencies often requires multiple layers of materials as well as trying to deal with angle of incidents, which also changes the effective impedance because the path length in the material changes. Then throw in the polarization of the waves and things get even funner.

Pro tips: For those who want their food cooked more evenly in a microwave, you want to place your food on the turntable that avoids the center as much as possible as the center has the food just spinning in place as opposed to the edges of the turntable where the food moves a much greater distance around in the microwave which translates to less cold spots. Second pro tip, correct wattage information for recipes, for most micowaves the wattage shown on the sticker inside the microwave just shows the "input" wattage of the microwave (but you might be lucky and have a sticker that says input and output). Usually this sticker will say 1500 watts or 1.5 kw or close too that. This is NOT your microwave wattage for use in recipes. This is just the amount of electricity your micowave draws from the power outlet, what you want for your food recipes is the output wattage. This can be harder to find in some cases especially if you don't have the owners manual of your microwave. An easy way to find this is to find the model number of your microwave (usually on one of the stickers on or inside your microwave) and google that model number and the word "specs". Then click one of the first links and it should tell you what your correct microwave wattage is. You may be shocked at what your actual wattage is, my microwave sticker says 1.5 kw (1500 watts) and the website showed the spec sheet for my microwave and it shows it as a 950 watt microwave. Now once you have the correct wattage of your microwave you want to lookup a conversion chart for microwave times so say if your hot pocket says the cook time is for 1100 watt microwaves and you have a 950 watt one like me then you can adjust the cook time correctly. https://www.microwavecookingforone.com/Charts/

So my point is, this seems like an awful lot of trouble to go through to reinvent our current lithography methods when they have such a limited improvement over current methods. Are they thinking that this process could be more power efficient or that a different material could end up being used which reduces the chance of quantum tunneling at that scale?

Or is it that this process might be more efficient from a waste perspective allowing manufacturers to increase yields and reduce waste while also improving the uniformity of their product?

For anyone thinking we could use this for technology: first, we already do in semiconductor lithography (literally the exact thing they mentioned in this video, yes it already exists and has for 20 years or more). Second, the amount of power it takes to power the microwave that causes this reaction is far greater than the resulting energy available in the plasma. Imagine how bright a 1000 watt light bulb would be next to this (most microwaves are around that range). We've got far better ways of creating plasma (fluorescent light bulbs do this) in much larger quantity and energy density. Not trying to be a downer--this was a fantastic video and a hilarious concept--it just doesn't have any practical implications we aren't already making use of.

Wow, talk about old new...this was hashed out at least 20 years ago to my knowledge at least. The grape halves are effectively converted to dipole antennas, and since their refraction and size makes it ideal for a microwave's wavelength, they swap energy between the narrow skin connecting them as the sine wave alternates between positive and negative from one pole to the other. This massive energy transfer through a small conductive media that heats quickly (grape skin), causes it to generate plasma.

Also, another easy way to generate plasma in a microwave if you don't have grapes, just stick a match in a small block of wood or similar to hold it vertical, light the match, then turn on the microwave. It's usually more impressive and reliable than the grape trick.

Veritasium - you said that "...a typical household microwave uses a frequency of electromagnetic radiation of about 2.45 GHz, that means that the wavelength of microwaves inside the oven is about 12 cm long..."

However, you did not explain why this is. Knowing one, does not always mean you know the other - but in this case we do. It would be nice if that was explained.

The wavelength is the distance between the same points between successive waves - measured in units of distance (metres, centimetres, millimetres, etc). That is, the wavelength is the distance between two peaks or troughs on successive waves.

The frequency is how many waves pass a given point per second. 1 Hz is one wave (or cycle) per second.

However, when we are talking about electromagnetic waves (e.g. light, radio waves including microwaves and millimetre waves, gamma rays, etc) all electromagnetic radiation travels at the same speed - around 3.0 x 10^8 metres per second (i.e. 300,000,000 metres per second or 300,000 kilometres per second - more precisely it is 299,792,458 metres per second).

As electromagnetic waves are always traveling at the same speed, the longer the wavelength, the smaller the frequency, and the smaller the wavelength the higher the frequency.

The general formula for frequency is the velocity divided by the wavelength, for electromagnetic waves frequency is always the speed of light (c) divided by the wavelength. So, for electromagnetic waves if we know the wavelength we can know the frequency and vice versa.

Doing the maths - 299792458 / (2.45 * 10^9) is approx.0.1224 metres or 12.24 cm

a few years back and right next to my house,  I saw ball lightning.   It was daylight on a summer afternoon, when a large storm front was approaching.  There was no rain yet.  I was standing in an adjacent parking lot talking to some friends and suddenly a shower of sparks came off nearby (like 70 foot) power lines.   A plasma ball (about the size of a beach ball) floated slowly across the street from left to right and over a parked vehicle in my driveway.  I walked up to that driveway and back to my house with one friend and another ball came right behind us.  It dissipated in a bright flash, maybe 12 feet from where we were standing.  The other folks still at the parking lot all saw it but were ignorant of its rarity and significance so didn't yank out their cellphones.  One observer guessed the diameter of the second ball around 5 feet right  before it died. (the first ball to my eye looked around  24-30 inches in diameter)   One thing I thought very odd - when the ball behind and above us dissipated into a hillside - there was a "zzzzzzzzttttttttttt" sound such as with one rising arc from a "Jacob's ladder".  Why might ball lightning make an "AC" buzz sound ? There was no smell of ozone nor noticeable burning of foliage.  How much energy might have been contained in those two balls?  What would it had done to "touch" one?
A basis for how the ancients used architecture to manipulate  energy.

It's not rocket science, the energy from a microwave is just like any other transmitter it is RF (Radio Frequency) AC (Alternating Current), it just happens to be at a very short way length, that short wavelength is what causes the plasma to sustain once created, with any antenna of 1/4 wavelength the antenna radiates both an electrostatic and and electromagnetic field, the electromagnetic radiation occurs near the feed point of the antenna and is perpendicular to the antenna while the electrostatic radiation is parallel to the antenna and radiated mostly from the top of the antenna furthest from the feed point, this is because near the feed point the current is very high, but as you move toward the top of the antenna, the current is gradually exchanged with voltage or potential, 1/4 wave antennas have a limit as to how much power you can feed them with before the voltage becomes so high that it breaks down the dielectric of air, causing it to become ionized, which means that it is no longer and insulator and it now begins to conduct current this causes it to become superheated to many thousands of degrees Fahrenheit until it starts to emit photons which we see as visible light, that is what we see radiated from the top of a Tesla coil, you notice that in many cases the discharge from a Tesla coil is radiated from a single terminal into the air and does not strike any thing except the air. Tesla coils operate at very low frequency as compared with a microwave, to put it in prospective for you the AC in a wall outlet changes its polarity 60 times per second or 60hz, therefore the 1/4 wavelength is about 750 miles, Tesla coils operate at frequencies of between 100 and 500khz or 100,000 to 500,000 times per second, so a 1/4 wavelength at these frequencies is much shorter, usually a few hundred feet, but in the case of the microwave it's much faster at 2.54Ghz that's a whopping 2,540,000,000 times per second so the wavelength is much much shorter, well for some reason it did not copy all of, or it did not past all of it, so let's see if I can copy and paste the rest of it in edit mode.

Firstly I apologise for this long comment.
Just because someone has an unpronounceable last name from an English perspective and a weird haircut does not make them right. Just a minute while I go and scramble my hair to get some credibility before I go on.
Firstly the refractive index of a material decreases with increasing wave length. An example of this is (blue bends best rule) in a prism dispersion spectrum. Blue has the higher frequency and smaller wave length than red at the other end of the visible spectrum. So blue has a wave length about 0.00005cms and red about double that. So the shorter wave length blue bends more, slows more and has a higher refractive index than red.
A microwave oven has about a 12cm wave length. This is a much longer wave length than visible spectrum red. Therefore oven microwaves have a much lower refractive index than any frequency in the visible spectrum. Therefore a microwave hitting a ball of water or lens surface in an oven will refract far less than if visible light hit the same lens surface.
The refractive index of water in the microwave spectrum is actually I am guessing about 0.00001X that in the visible spectrum. Not 10X as stated in this video.
So the microwaves are hardly bending or refracting at all when they hit the curved lens surface be it a grape or a ball of water in a bead. There is definitely no internal reflection within the ball of water amplifying or focusing the power of the microwaves.
This refractive, internal reflection, index theory does not explain how in the first experiment the flat surface of the grape was presented to the microwaves and yet the effect occurred. It also makes the assumption that the microwaves are linear in direction in an oven when they are not. Microwaves actually bounce around the walls of the oven loosing energy until they are absorbed by matter like water.
What is actually happening is the water molecules are heating up in the grape and at the point of greatest pressure encapsulation it is boiling and then those gaseous water molecules charged hydrogen arms are less restricted by neighbouring water molecules so they absorb and store more energy, then resonating and increasing in energy to such a level that the plasma effect can occur. So this superheated gas turning into plasma.
The surface of the water spheres (or grapes) are also electrically charged by the microwaves and the point at which they touch has the least negative charge. At that point is where the encapsulated plasma negative electrons head to burst out of the sphere. In its own heat the plasma rises in the microwave air eventually fading out while it makes the air probably around it glow.
So water in the grape is turned to steam at that point where there is the greatest encapsulation of mass or around the grape centre. That steam is super heated because the water molecules are less restricted thus amplifying their stored energy allowing them to reach the plasma state or phase. So the plasma already exists inside the grape and is also glowing if you look. The electrons in that plasma head towards the area of least negative charge which is the area where the grapes touch. It is the like negative surface charge on the grapes which is making the grapes move apart initially. As gravity forces them together again the negative charge on the surfaces moves away from the point of contact. This allows the point where the internal negative plasma wants to escape to.

When we got our first microwave oven in 1988, I placed two cooked/hydrated pinto beans in the microwave. They were approximately 0.1” apart, mayby a tiny bit closer. I wanted to see what the microwave would do to two beans, mostly to see how quickly it would heat them. After setting the time to 10 seconds, I turned it on and then stared through the door to see what would happen, but after about 1-2 seconds I saw a blue arc come between the two beans.

Being 10 years old, I freaked out and stopped the microwave before it got to 10 seconds and told nobody about it, thinking that I would get in trouble for “breaking” the microwave...the microwave was fine, no complaints. Years later I remembered this pinto bean spark and tried it but could not replicate it. Then again, I only re-attempted it once.

Originally, the beans were whole, cooked in water with salt and onion. They were pulled out of the pot and placed side by side on the platter. What I don’t clearly remember is how they were oriented when they went arc-y-sparky.

Several points.

I think the difference in the refractive index of the grape and the grape skin is critically important.

The radio wave travels through the grape pulp, bounces off the skin and is reflected back to the other side of the grape.

The shape of the grape is critical too. The grape skin provides an internal mirror, focusing the energy back to the tow, opposite points. This is why the effect works with the water beads.

Of course, most of the energy is escaping, however the oven is supplying power needed to maintain the effect.

Possibly I can add some of my analysis to this very interesting experiment.

From an antenna perspective, (in this case I believe you have built a circular (two grapes) dipole).

To help explain the importance of the size of the grapes, as the length to diameter ratio of the dipole elements gets smaller and smaller, the resonate frequency of the antenna becomes lower than the free space wavelength and the bandwidth of the antenna increases and in this case, reaches 1:1 for a circle or spherical dipole.
A standard dipole may have a length to diameter ratio, as an example, of 5000:1 for a wire antenna in the HF region or maybe 50:1 for a tubular antenna the VHF region.

Since the resonate frequency of the elements are shortened by being circular, the diameter of the each grape becomes resonate at 1/4 wavelength on each side of the dipole.

As you mention, the wavelength of the microwave 2.4 GHz is approximately 120 mm but maximum positive to negative voltage across a dipole occurs at 1/2 wavelength (60 mm) or (30 mm for 1/4 wavelength for each side).

How much the index of refraction of water affects this antenna, I am not sure but for water is stated as 1.33 which does not explain the resonance.

That, in my opinion, is the "antenna action" of the two grapes at this frequency.

hey - sorry to break this to you... i'm not sure the scientists got it quite right yet. this doesn't cover my observations--where i get plasma discharge with other 'squishy' stuff--such as between 2 little peas or 2 carrots touching in the microwave--and those peas are only 8mm in size--much smaller grapes, while the carrots are much larger.

so far, my microwave has survived, but the flashes and sound are intense, and it's fairly scary. i have to spend time separating them out/putting space between them before i start the mw, so they don't arc like that.

either my plasma is caused by different factors, or this theory needs more tweaking. my arcs and plasma are surely at the point the 2 peas/carrots touch -- i can see it as it happens, and then the scorch marks are very precise -- including the melding of the peas to each-other -- just like the grapes welding together in the video.

it happens most often with fruit or veggies that are frozen and/or have a lot of sugar. so, i have always assumed there was something about the sugar/carbs or ice crystals that created a field or somehow created the discharge and set off the plasma.

also, an engineer i know (who has witnessed the plasma from my peas and carrots), has pointed out to me that the discharge flow toward the top of the mw cavity is likely caused by the grounded metal of the magneton.

Here's what I see: the grape- or water gel bead- is functioning as a meta-material (and you should look up the Bell Labs work of Shively, who made artificial dielectric microwave lenses); the grapes are essentially both antennas and cavity resonators and because of their shape are also functioning as refractive lenses, just like the Bell microwave lenses but using the cavity effect rather than a passing microwave front. IOWs, the microwave energy is coming from the inside out rather than being supplied from outside the "lense". (What I mean is, the plasma is from concentrated microwave energy, which the microwaves inside the oven aren't normally able to do. But when the resonance inside the cavity takes place, THAT concentrated and focused energy is what is making the plasma generation possible.) In fact, like Anton van Leuwenhouk's(sp?) glass bead microscopes, the focal point is almost on the surface of the sphere, which helps explain why when two of them are touching it becomes essentially focused on the point of contact and able to swap back and forth between the two grapes...

For me, it means I may start experimenting with 2.4 GHz solid dielectric antennas- omni-directional radiators of a size dictated by the dielectric constant of the material with a piece of coax terminated at the center of a sphere. It doesn't have to be water inside- it could be plastic or glass, as long as the diameter and dielectric constant gave a one wavelength cavity resonator. Things could get really interesting if you made a phased array....which, BTW, what TWO grapes touching represent...

I don't think we can improve current lithography technics this way.


You see, the problem with decreasing the size of microchips today isn't that of engineering ways to make even smaller features. It's a problem with quantum physics: there are some effects happening in a transistor that we still don't understand exactly, especially one called "Quantum Tunneling", by which electrons jump the energy barrier that is fundamental to its functionality. These effects increase tremendously when we approach some threshold where the transistor gate is near one molecule thin.


So, people have come up with smart ways to avoid this problem with engineering, but that's not about making things smaller. Moore's law is condemned already and people are starting to begin researching other ways of making computers. Quantum Computing or some sort of biological approach might be fields that will come up with new ways of processing information.


But lithography is certainly on its saturation point. PS.: I'm a computer engineer and that's the most amazing topic I studied back in college.

Interesting remark on the lithography; we have had that sort of technology for a while using metal tips on AFM (analogous to tip enhanced Raman scattering); where a tip (usually gold) is brought near the surface, when exposed to light the gold is excited (surface plasmon resonance) which induces a dipole in the material it is near. If the material is also a metal, or a thin film on a metal (like say a lithography mask on gold) then the field enhancement (and the ability to manipulate the mask) is confined to a fraction of the tip size - these tips often have a radius of 5 nm, and so we have field localization of about 2 nm.

There are also probe microscopes made for manufacturing which have many tips on one driving head so you can write multiple chips at the same time; the drawback, is that unlike optical masks which let you write the whole surface at one time; probes require going over the whole surface - which also limits the size.

This could assist with lithography by perhaps making small features more easily constructed in general, but I'm not sure it would help decrease feature size that much. The current lithography limit is about 14nm (that's the Knights Landing), and I think Intel intends to get down to 11nm. For the first order of magnitude, finer resolution is the obstacle, but the next order of magnitude is in the realm of a width of a silicon atom, about 0.2 nm. At that point manufacturing becomes very difficult and any mistake could corrupt calculations. So lithography resolution is only half the battle, we might also need completely new technology to keep Moore's law going.

Like you did, I would not imagine such a huge change in index of refraction over the frequency range, even though I have been very familiar with absorbance changes over a relatively narrow frequency range.

Another satisfying point is the broadening of resonance peaks due to absorption. This is one thing that lab researchers on resonance want to avoid. But in this case, it helps bring the phenomenon to household testers.

The only problem with the theoretical technique of EUVL (Extreme UltraViolet Lithography) in this video, is that once you shrink your transistor to a small enough size; you get annoying quantum sized problems like quantum tunneling. Quantum tunneling is when your transistor is so small, electrons can phase over to the other side of the "gate" which is obviously catastrophic to the functioning of a computer(It won't destroy the computer, but it can cause corruption in the code). IBM is working on making transistors the size of 5nm and they are ditching the FinFET architecture; but any smaller than that and you WILL have problems. 2nm might only be achievable with carbon which has properties that allow it to negate the effects of quantum tunneling, but at 2nm it is still unlikely, and moores law is dead anyways...

The same physics still applies.

Safety wise, there's different implications.
We don't get to generate plasma, but there are incidences of focused electromagnetic fields causing burns in MRI; Though not common and can be avoided if proper safety practices are followed.

Small detail : because of the voltage doubler made of a capacitor in series with the output of the transformer, at 2000 volts AC and a diode that connects between the output and the ground (which happen to be positive), the magnetron is turned on only of one side of the 60 hz wave (let's call it, the positive side) and the magnetron is off for the full half cycle.


The reason is that the capacitor charge to 2000 volts on half cycle, then the 2000 volt of the capacitor adds to the 2000 volt of the transformer, giving the peak of 4kv. In practice, the voltage will saturate to the level where the magnetron trigger and fall rapidly. Brief, the shape in a short pulse of a few millisecond and nothing for the rest of the 16 ms cycle.


The half cycle would be called "50% duty cycle". The real active part is less than 50%.

Look at a GPS antenna sometime, it will blow your mind the thing is only 2-3cm and the wavelength of 1.575ghz is close to 19cm! Thanks to a special ceramic that has a high dielectric constant (index of refraction). We use this effect in the RF industry all the time to focus RF, male antennas smaller, phase antennas together! I once did a test using water in a ziplock bag between the driven element and groundplane of a patch antenna. The issue with this is what water absorbs RF at the frequencies we where working with so it was very lossy! So we tried ice and had some success but the dielectric constant isn’t as good for ice witch results in a larger antenna. Love the dark magic of RF wizardry

To make plasma (or a high curent spot) in the microwave you don't need grapes you just need to make a dipole inside. A dipole which has a small gap or small conductive path in between the dipole poles. The small path will have a higher electric resistance which will result in more heat beeing generated which can lead to plasma. The interesting thing is that this dipole can be made from many different materials. From small metal pieces to meat or wet toothpicks (it didn't work.. I think if you use wood it has to be realy soaked with water.. like keep it in water days.

The grape is not really important here, if you can design a tuned spherical cavity resonator with an outlet and tune the microwave emitter wavelength and position to focus the microwaves in the center of the resonator, with a single outlet, and produce massive amplification, you can produce thrust in a vacuum from only microwaves! You could even boost this by adding a valve on the outlet, and an injector where you can put in tiny amounts of hydrogen or xenon or argon in the chamber, which gives you basically a pulse detonation microwave plasma engine! Microwaves heat up the gas, cause it to expand and raise pressure in the chamber, at which point the valve opens exhausting the plasma and the microwaves in one massive pulse of thrust. You can run the engine with no propellant, valve open, for essentially infinite ISP and constant trickle acceleration (so long as you can generate electricity) AND boost it with hydrogen, xenon or argon if you need more momentary thrust, such as for deceleration! Also, this implies that you can pretty much build these engines at any scale, provided you can accommodate the resonator size and emitter wavelength and power.

Actually it doesn't matter what you put in the microwave, so long as it's capable of heating to the point of creating a flame. Once a flame is produced, the microwaves super heat the flame creating a plasma, and because the resulting plasma is electrically conductive, it responds similarly to placing metal in a microwave. This sustains the plasma keeping it going as electric currents eddy, spark, and swirl through the plasma and you get the resulting crackling and even the sound of the plasma itself as it cycles at a resonance with magnetron. Place a lit match in a microwave or even a piece of burning paper, and you will get plasma within seconds.

I had a hard time understanding why the grape's refractive index changed the wavelength, because I incorrectly assumed that meant it changed the frequency (which doesn't make sense). After doing some reading, I looked up the equation: wavelength (λ)= velocity (v)/frequency (f). Which means frequency can be unaffected, and a decrease in velocity = decrease in wavelength.

In terms of application, some physicists rightly point out that smaller and smaller chip features lead to unwanted quantum tunneling. But I don't think this is going to be the ultimate limiting factor of moore's law. Instead of fighting with quantum tunneling, the next generation of chips might be able to leverage quantum tunneling, which kinda blurs the lines between classical computers and quantum computers.

They wouldn't be truly quantum computers because they don't make use of superposition to perform parallel computations on the same bit. But they wouldn't be truly classical computers because they leverage quantum effects, at least more than before. It'd be closer to classical computations using quantum effects.
